info.game_comments:
2001 Tournament of Champions quarterfinal game 3.

(Sarah: I'm Sarah, and we're the Clue Crew.  Swimming today on Jeopardy! Everybody into the pool!)
(Cheryl: I don't think so.)
(Sarah: Hey, guys!  What's up?)
(Sofia: Buh-bye!  How about lunch?)
(Cheryl: Oh yeah!)
(Sarah: Guys!)

(1, 1).clue: In May 2001 Erik Weihenmayer climbed Everest, not considering this condition of his a handicap

(2, 1).clue: Felipa Perestrello married this explorer but died soon after their son Diego was born in 1480

(3, 1).clue: Beginning in 1978 it was the Barnes family versus the Ewings on this prime-time soap

(4, 1).clue: Of the original 13 colonies, this one had the first permanent European settlement

(5, 1).clue: During the holidays you can buy this cool creamy Christmas drink in cartons, minus the liquor

(6, 1).clue: In song it's "A name I call myself"

(1, 2).clue: Its southern slope extends down to Suruga Bay near Tokyo

(2, 2).clue: Logic would say this philosopher was married to Pythias, either the niece or adopted daughter of Hermias

(3, 2).clue: On this series as Kwai Chang Caine David Carradine showed off his martial arts skills

(4, 2).clue: In early 1665 New Haven Colony merged with this one

(5, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew ready to fall backwards into a swimming pool.)  I'm about to take this drink company's famous plunge from TV ads

(1, 3).clue: It's the mountain chain in the names of a U.S. sheep & goat

(2, 3).clue: A "window" into this businessman's world shows he married Melinda French, a product manager at his company

(3, 3).clue: "The Bionic Woman", launched in 1976, was developed from this series

(4, 3).clue: This colony began with a 1704 meeting of the general assembly for New Castle, Kent & Sussex Counties

(5, 3).clue: Tuborg is a famous beer from this country

(6, 3).clue: Julia Sweeney's experiences with cancer inspired her one-woman show, "God Said" this!

(1, 4).clue: The Hudson River rises in this group of mountains in northeast New York

(2, 4).clue: Soong Ch'ing-ling wed revolutionary leader Sun Yat-sen; her sister Mei-Ling married this nationalist leader

(3, 4).clue: Following co-star Freddie Prinze's death in 1977, this sitcom continued for another season

(4, 4).clue: In the early 1700s, plantation owners in this colony developed a breed of horse called the Narragansett Pacer

(5, 4).clue: Add cherry brandy & seasonings to melted gruyere cheese & you'll have this classic dipping dish

(6, 4).clue: An Italian river, or the red Teletubby

(1, 5).clue: The Lebanon Mountains' most famous remaining grove of these trees is near the town of Bsharre

(2, 5).clue: Rupert Pole married this diarist in 1955 even though she was still married to Hugo Guiler

(3, 5).clue: David Birney & Meredith Baxter married for real after playing a couple on this show

(4, 5).clue: The Calvert family governed this colony for much of the time between 1632 & the Revolutionary War

(5, 5).clue: A Southern specialty, Hoppin' John is made with pork, rice & these peas

(1, 1).clue: In 1971 this future secretary-general was a candidate for the presidency of Austria

(2, 1).clue: In 2000 Marla Maples auctioned off for $110,000 the engagement ring she got from this ex

(3, 1).clue: Anya Seton's novel "Katherine" is based on John of Gaunt's affair with this "Canterbury Tales"-spinner's sister-in-law

(5, 1).clue: This lemon-lime soft drink debuted in October 1929 in green 7-ounce bottles

(6, 1).clue: This should mean a grifter's rocky hideout, not curved like the inner surface of a sphere

(1, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew is at the United Nations.)  She was the first woman to sit here as U.S. ambassador to the U.N.

(2, 2).clue: We wonder "How Does It Feel" to own this rock legend's boyhood home in Duluth, Minn.; it sold on eBay for $82,000

(3, 2).clue: Reading this 1961 novel by Irving Stone might inspire you to paint your ceiling

(4, 2).clue: "Deathrace 2000","Over the Top","Stop!  Or My Mom Will Shoot"

(5, 2).clue: He made M'm! M'm! Good! when he joined a Camden, N.J. canning company in 1869; he later took it over

(6, 2).clue: This should mean someone who rides a bike, not someone who travels about selling wares

(1, 3).clue: One of the six principal organs of the U.N. is this special 15-country council

(2, 3).clue: Her head went on the block in 1587 & in 2001 a wee bit of her royal hair was on the block, going for $2,700

(3, 3).clue: Wild Bill Hickok turns up in "Boone's Lick", a 2000 novel by this "Lonesome Dove" author

(4, 3).clue: "The Little Girl Who Lives Down the Lane","Freaky Friday","Maverick"

(5, 3).clue: In 1930 Sears transferred this tire brand name to its insurance division

(6, 3).clue: This should mean a useful hat, not a physical disability

(1, 4).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew  is outside the U.N. building.)  The land the U.N. complex is built on was donated by this wealthy businessman

(2, 4).clue: Sotheby's could have said, "Show me the millions" when it auctioned off one of this artist's "Haystacks" in 2001

(3, 4).clue: "Gates of Fire" is an epic novel about this battle lost by the Spartans in 480 B.C.

(5, 4).clue: Entrepreneurs William Russell, Alexander Majors & William B. Waddell founded this in 1860; it lasted 18 months

(6, 4).clue: This should mean a distant object, not an old British quarter-penny

(1, 5).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew is outside the U.N. building.)  It's the U.N. goal & the reference from Isaiah expressed by the U.N. headquarters statue seen here

(2, 5).clue: A pair of globes used by this Flemish cartographer went for $1.7 million in 1991

(3, 5).clue: Set during the last days of the Civil War, this debut novel by Charles Frazier is often compared to the "Odyssey"

(4, 5).clue: "Grease 2","Amazon Women on the Moon","The Fabulous Baker Boys"

(5, 5).clue: This athletic shoe company's internet store is located at catshack.com

(6, 5).clue: This should mean "what professionals charge", not "to divide proportionately"

(0, 0).clue: The highest-rated sports program in TV history, other than a Super Bowl, took place on Feb. 23, 1994 in this sport
